summary: This is a July 2020 letter from Acting U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss to attorney Robert Glassman, responding to a request for documents related to Jeffrey Epstein and a civil case. The letter states that certain documents (FedEx invoices, materials from electronic search warrants, and a photo from Epstein's residence) are being provided, while noting that grand jury materials cannot be disclosed.

persons.name: Robert Glassman
persons.context: Addressee of the letter; sent a request on June 8, 2020, for documents related to Jeffrey Epstein and a plaintiff in a civil case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the case; documents related to him are being provided in response to a Touhy request.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Author of the letter; responds to the document request and authorizes the release of certain materials.

connections.description: Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is formally responding to Glassman's document request on behalf of the DOJ.
Glassman is seeking documents related to Epstein in connection with a civil litigation (Jane Doe v. Indyke et al.).

events.title: Document Request Letter
events.description: Attorney Robert Glassman sends a letter to the DOJ requesting documents related to Jeffrey Epstein and plaintiff Jane Doe in a civil case.

events.title: DOJ Response and Document Production
events.description: Acting U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss responds to Glassman's request, authorizing the release of certain documents (FedEx invoices, search warrant materials, a photo) while withholding grand jury materials.

locations: 86 Chambers Street, New York, New York 10007
Jeffrey Epstein's residence (location unspecified, subject of a physical search)
keyFacts: The DOJ, via Acting U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss, produced documents in July 2020 in response to a Touhy request from attorney Robert Glassman related to Jeffrey Epstein.

The produced documents included FedEx invoices (pages USDOL0001-0040), materials from electronic search warrants (pages USDOL0041-0052), and a photo from a physical search of Epstein's residence (page USDOJ_0053).
The DOJ explicitly stated it could not provide any documents governed by grand jury secrecy rules (Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 6(e)).
The document request was connected to the civil litigation 'Jane Doe v. Indyke et al., No. 20-cv-484 (S.D.N.Y.)'.
Information in the provided documents was redacted to exclude references to third parties.
